"If you are very new to Java, then please search the web for a 
tutorial on=
 how to set the CLASSPATH for a Java application"

I am very new to Java. I=
 executed on your advice by using Mastering 
the Java CLASSPATH by Keven Bo=
one 
(http://www.kevinboone.com/classpath.html). I used Boone's white 
pape=
r because it just deals w/ classes and no packages. I needed to 
start w/ou=
t the complication of package =3D path. The white paper 
resulted in 14 exe=
rcises 
(http://www.ypl.com/java/environment_variables/class_path/boone_ken=
/do
c/rl_notes/html/index.html).

Sorry about the delay in response. Howeve=
r, it now seems that I am 
going to have to get serious about Java.


--- I=
n junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> 
wrote:
>
> rob=
erto_lucente wrote:
> 
> > OS: Windows NT 4.0 SP6a
> > Java: 1.4.2_04-b05
>=
 > 
> >  >From the dos prompt I run the following via a .bat
> > 
> > set c=
lasspath=3DH:\languages\java\JUnit\junit3.8.1
> > \junit.jar;H:\languages\j=
ava\JUnit\junit3.8.1
> > \junit.jar;H:\languages\java\JUnit\junit3.8.1
> > =
\junit\tests\runner;H:\languages\java\JUnit\junit3.8.1
\junit\samples;
> 
>=
 Bad classpath!
> 
> Problem #1, you have junit.jar on there twice. Remove =
one.
> Problem #2, you have ./junit/tests/runner and ./junit/samples on 
th=
ere, 
> which won't work. Remove them, then add:
> 
> h:\languages\java\JUn=
it\junit3.8.1
> 
> If you are very new to Java, then please search the web =
for a 
tutorial 
> on how to set the CLASSPATH for a Java application.
> 
>=
 Good luck.
